Committed to Preserving the Wonders of Our WorldTransportation-Related Fuel
Use
By far the most significant resource we use in our 
operation, as measured by volume, weight, or any 
other relevant metric, is transportation-related fuels 
(over 99 percent, as measured in BTUs), primarily jet 
fuel consumed in aircraft but also gasoline and diesel 
for fleet vehicles and ground support equipment.  
Just how much fuel do we use? Combined, American 
Airlines and American Eagle used more than 3 billion 
gallons of jet fuel in 2007. While this may sound like a 
large number at first, consider that it is less than the 
volume of fuel used by U.S. cars and trucks in just two 
weeks. It allowed us to carry more than 121 million 
passengers and almost 700,000 tons of cargo for an 
average distance of 861 miles. 
 
Fuel Conservation*
Just as greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reduction 
may be vital to the health of our planet, fuel 
conservation is vital to our company’s financial 
health. Happily, the two work hand in hand — every 
gallon of fuel saved results in lower expenses and 
fewer GHG emissions.
